I agree this is a tad complex but honestly I dig this more than people saying to keep it as is, change the courses needed to declare, or to just consider courses taken so far for declaration (last one screws over people who were hoping to pull themselves up with the last course). It takes into account the fact that this is a very difficult semester, so if you do need to count this semester's performance into the average, then you deserve to have the bar be slightly lower (I like having it at ~3.1) to make up for all the trouble this time around. And then if you want to throw away this semester's performance completely, the P/NP is there too. I haven't put too much thought into what potential issues can come up, but tbh I could get behind this.
this will add more complication to a situation that is already extremely complicated due to p/np and whatnot

Thanks for the suggestion. The faculty are having conversations about to address major declaration. They want to consider all the complexities, which is why they haven't come out with a policy just yet. We will send an update as soon as we can.

Hang in there!

Dear EECS Department, 

With all due respect to the department, I have a suggestion I would like to make. I did not know where else to post this, so I thought making this new post was appropriate. 

Because of the unexpected rise of COVID-19, our academic experience has been compromised. This affects our academics and learning abilities (not to mention academic performance) greatly, as clearly acknowledged with the P/NP grading option announcement for Spring 2020. 

I understand that this will affect the 3.3 GPA declaration cap for L&S. For that I have a suggestion. I understand I am just a student but I firmly believe that we all have a voice and I hope someone reads this. 

My proposed solution:

A student can choose to P/NP ONE of the major declaration classes that they are CURRENTLY in (i.e. CS61B if the student is in CS61B right now). If the student is in multiple major declaration classes (i.e. CS 61B and CS 70) they have the option of using P/NP on still only ONE of those classes, so the other must be taken for a letter grade (i.e. Student is in 61B and 70, but chooses to P/NP 61B while taking 70 for a letter grade). Now, since the student has at least two of the three major declaration prerequisites taken for a letter grade, they must meet a 3.3 GPA with those two letter graded classes. 

Now the other part of my solution, if a student chooses to not use a P/NP option this semester for their major declaration class (i.e. student chooses not to P/NP 61B this semester, and take it for a letter grade), then they must meet a 3.2 GPA threshold with all three prerequisite classes to declare the major. If someone is in two major declaration pre-requisite classes, and elect NOT to use a P/NP for EITHER one of those courses, then all three of the prerequisites will be used to calculate if they reach a 3.2 GPA threshold. If they choose to P/NP one of those classes, then see the scenario in the previous paragraph. 

Once again, by no means am I chastising anyone, trying to shade anybody nor any any party involved. Quite frankly kudos to the EECS department for handling themselves with organization and finesse in such a panic-driven time. I am offering my suggestion and I mean all the respect in the world to the faculty and staff who work hard in the EECS department. 

I know the EECS department is working hard and I hate to be an add-on with this post, but I wanted to express my opinion. 

Thank you and stay healthy :)
